text: It'S just how it goes sometimes. Laser focus. All right, so Axie Infinity is a Pokemon inspired universe. So they're based on gelato. They're cute little four legged creatures, and they have six different body parts, and then they have a genetic code, and each one can be bred with each other, limited at times to make new axes. It's inspired from the game cryptokitties, if any of you are familiar with that. However, it's like if the cryptokitties could do stuff if they could battle, and then once we have our land gameplay that's coming out in like six to ten months ish, they'll be able to farm resources kind of in like an animal crossing type environment sort of thing. So right now, the primary utility from axies comes from their ability to battle, which is in groups of three. So really, to play the game, you have to buy three axies from the marketplace, and then you can use them in the adventure or in like the PvP competitive arena mode. There's a rating system, and when you compete in either of those modes and you're successful, you get these things called SLP, smooth love potions. And the smooth love potions are the backbone of the whole economy. You use those potions to breed axes and you get them as rewards for just playing the game. And that mechanism right there is really what encompasses this play to earn concept, where there's demand on both sides, where you have some people playing the game to farm SLP to cash out. Then you have some people playing the game basically to farm or buy SLP so that they can breed and extend their farm. This idea of scholarships are basically people that have a lot of axies bringing in players that either can't afford them, are saving up to afford their first set of axies, and then they loan them an account with some starters, then they grind, and then the SLP that gets produced gets split between the manager and the scholar. So it's sort of like a win win, since there's a fixed amount of, well, a semi finite amount of axes in existence. We have more people that want to play than we have axes. So if you think about that kind of queue, this is a way for players that have, let's say, 100 axes to benefit from having that many while giving other people access to the game. So it creates this ecosystem that's sort of a win win for everyone. And I think that scholarship aspect has been the secret to our explosive growth over the last couple months. Specifically.
